items.title: Taking faculty diversity seriously means asking why it matters
items.author: Azim Shariff
items.content: Increasing faculty diversity is a key priority in faculty hiring across many countries, but the rationales behind it are often left undiscussed. Explicitly clarifying diversity rationales — and ensuring they are supported by scientific evidence — can improve hiring committee decision making.

items.title: A cognitive approach to human–AI complementarity in dynamic decision-making
items.author: Hoda Heidari
items.content: Complex decision-making tasks can be addressed with artificial intelligence (AI) systems that complement human capabilities. In this Perspective, Gonzalez and Heidari provide a conceptual framework to integrate human and AI decision-making, highlighting technical challenges and ethical risks.

items.title: Mental health and treatment challenges in older adults
items.author: Sunil Bhar
items.content: As life expectancy increases globally, psychotherapy for people aged 65 years and above must become more specialized and competent. In this Review, Laidlaw et al. describe findings from gerontological and psychological research that seek to improve mental health interventions in late life and enhance older adults’ emotional capabilities and motivations.

items.title: Citation diversity statements
items.content: Nature Reviews Psychology is encouraging authors to include a citation diversity statement to draw attention to citation imbalances and confirm that they made efforts to cite publications from a diverse group of researchers.
